quotes.topic_title: SaaS sales is problem-solving, not selling
quotes.text: Here's the mistake that 99% of founders and sales reps make. We're not really selling in B2B, we're solving problems.
quotes.speaker: Jason Lemkin
quotes.context: Reframes SaaS sales as problem-solving rather than persuasion, a mindset shift that changes how reps run discovery and build trust.

quotes.topic_title: SaaS sales is problem-solving, not selling
quotes.text: Our job as sales reps in SaaS is to not sell a used car, okay? We are selling a Tesla Model 3 performance.
quotes.speaker: Jason Lemkin
quotes.context: A memorable analogy that pushes practitioners to sell like a premium, differentiated product—consultative, not transactional.

quotes.topic_title: SaaS sales is problem-solving, not selling
quotes.text: I've spent four calls answering all your questions and I've explained to you all the things and why the supercharging network is better than the regular one that doesn't really work at the charger near your house.
quotes.speaker: Jason Lemkin
quotes.context: Illustrates the practical work of consultative selling: patient education, objection handling, and tailoring value to the buyer’s situation.

quotes.topic_title: SaaS sales is problem-solving, not selling
quotes.text: I've gone on Google and I've seen there's no charging network near your house. There's only Superchargers. I got you, don't I?
quotes.speaker: Jason Lemkin
quotes.context: Shows a concrete method—do external homework on the customer’s constraints—to proactively solve problems and earn credibility.

quotes.topic_title: SaaS sales is problem-solving, not selling
quotes.text: That's the job of SaaS and sales because we're not selling commodities.
quotes.speaker: Jason Lemkin
quotes.context: A positioning principle: if your product is differentiated, your sales motion should emphasize diagnosis and fit, not price-driven tactics.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: In our conversation, we focus on what I find most product leaders have the least experience in, building a sales team.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Frames the episode around a common gap for product leaders—practical sales team building.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: We get very practical and tactical on how long you should wait to hire your first salesperson, what your one to two first hire should look like, why you should actually hire two salespeople, not just one initially, how to comp them, how to interview them, when it's time to hire a VP of sales, how to avoid your salespeople flaming out and burning through all your cash.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: A dense checklist of actionable sales-hiring decisions and failure modes to plan for.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: We also get into how to make the product and sales relationship healthier, including how to push back on sales and feature requests, why your head of product should be super involved in your sales process, how long you should make your trials, why you should avoid annual contracts, and so much more.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Highlights concrete levers for improving product–sales collaboration, including a contrarian stance on annual contracts.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: Before Saastr, Jason was the CEO and co-founder of EchoSign, which he grew to over 100 million ARR and then sold to Adobe where he ended up as a vice president of their web services business.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Establishes a specific scale benchmark (100M ARR) underpinning the credibility of the advice.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: These popups are becoming less and less effective since most users don't read what they say, they just want to close them as soon as possible, but every product builder knows that users need help to learn the ins and outs of your product.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Highlights a practical product-growth problem: traditional in-product tours are losing effectiveness even though user education remains essential.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: They use AI to get closer to user intent, so they have search and chat products that let users describe what they're trying to do in their own words and then see personalized results like customer walkthroughs or actions.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Offers an actionable methodology for in-product help: shift from feature-push to intent-driven search/chat with personalized guidance.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: their nudges are based on in-product behaviors like confusion or intent classification, which makes them much less annoying and much more impactful.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Provides a concrete tactic for improving in-app messaging by triggering nudges from behavioral signals rather than generic prompts.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Over 15 million end-users have interacted with CommandBar.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: A specific adoption data point that signals scale and real-world usage of the approach described.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Over 5,000 fast-growing companies use Vanta to automate up to 90% of the work involved with SOC 2 and these other frameworks.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Quantifies the potential operational leverage from compliance automation with a concrete benchmark ("up to 90%").

quotes.topic_title: Why sales-team building stays confusing
quotes.text: I think it's great. I think it's an evergreen topic, but I think there's remains a consistent set of confusion, fears around how to build a sales team, and it's evergreen.
quotes.speaker: Jason Lemkin
quotes.context: Frames sales-team building as a recurring, evergreen challenge driven by persistent founder confusion and fear.

quotes.topic_title: Why sales-team building stays confusing
quotes.text: The tools change and the pace has changed, but the issues, I love to dig into them because we keep making the same mistakes as founders and executives again and again and again.
quotes.speaker: Jason Lemkin
quotes.context: A durable mental model: despite changing tooling and market speed, the core failure modes repeat—so learning should focus on recurring mistakes.

quotes.topic_title: Why sales-team building stays confusing
quotes.text: It's such a black box to me. Sales, I've never done sales, and I'm always just like, "I have no idea what's going on here."
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Highlights how opaque sales can feel to many founders/operators, motivating the need for clearer systems and education.

quotes.topic_title: Do you need sales or can PLG work?
quotes.text: The most important thing though I've found is however you get those first 10, 15, 20 customers, be honest, be honest, and if you've talked to them as a founder and you know that they need a sales type motion, they need effort to deploy it, they have questions about security, they have questions about competition, they have onboarding requirements, and you say, "Hey, I don't like sales, so I'm going to do a PLG motion," you'll fail.
quotes.speaker: Jason Lemkin
quotes.context: A blunt test: let early customer requirements dictate your go-to-market motion, not founder preference.

quotes.topic_title: Do you need sales or can PLG work?
quotes.text: One of the things that I've done with so many founders over the years, and it shocks them at first, is your first 10, 15, 50 unaffiliated customers, the ones that find you from the ether, they're the next 50, 100, 200, 1,000, and you can either embrace them or run for them.
quotes.speaker: Jason Lemkin
quotes.context: A mental model for early traction: your initial “random” customers are predictive of your scalable customer base.

quotes.topic_title: Do you need sales or can PLG work?
quotes.text: I'll tell you a company I invested in 18 months ago when things were easier, maybe 20 months ago, they were doing 5 million in revenue, growing over 100% with the sales like motion. Things got harder, things got harder as they did for many of us, and they decided to fire the whole sales team, and now they're doing less than one from 5 million with beloved customers.
quotes.speaker: Jason Lemkin
quotes.context: A cautionary example showing how removing sales can collapse revenue even with strong customer love.

quotes.topic_title: Do you need sales or can PLG work?
quotes.text: Even worse, sometimes worse is your first 10 customers, five of them sign up online, but it takes a huge amount of effort for 19 bucks a month, and then five say they'll pay you $5,000 a month. Some founders are like, "I'm going to work on the five that pay us 20 bucks a month, not the five that'll pay us $5,000 a year."
quotes.speaker: Jason Lemkin
quotes.context: A counterintuitive warning: founders who avoid sales often choose the lower-value path despite clear willingness to pay.

quotes.topic_title: Do you need sales or can PLG work?
quotes.text: Too many founders in the beginning think it's either or. It's not either or.
quotes.speaker: Jason Lemkin
quotes.context: A simple reframing that encourages hybrid PLG + sales models instead of false dichotomies.

quotes.topic_title: Founders must close first customers themselves
quotes.text: Even if you hate sales, even if you think it's icky, even if you don't like it, as a founder you've, 95 times out of 100, you've got to find a way at least to close the first 10 customers yourself.
quotes.speaker: Jason Lemkin
quotes.context: Clear, actionable rule-of-thumb that founders should personally close the earliest customers before scaling sales.

quotes.topic_title: Founders must close first customers themselves
quotes.text: The hack though is that even if you don't like sales, customers love to talk to the CEO.
quotes.speaker: Jason Lemkin
quotes.context: Counterintuitive leverage point: founder-led sales works because early customers value direct access to the CEO.

quotes.topic_title: Founders must close first customers themselves
quotes.text: almost all founders are A+ middlers, A+ middlers, A+ middlers.
quotes.speaker: Jason Lemkin
quotes.context: Memorable mental model that founders excel in the “middle” of sales conversations (deep product/problem discussion).

quotes.topic_title: Founders must close first customers themselves
quotes.text: So find a way to get any prospects, get really good at the middle, and then work up your courage. Work up your courage, and find how to ask for next steps and money.
quotes.speaker: Jason Lemkin
quotes.context: Practical methodology: focus on getting prospects, dominate the core conversation, then deliberately practice the ask.

quotes.topic_title: Founders must close first customers themselves
quotes.text: The beauty to founders is they don't need help in the middle. You can be 10 times better in the middle than any sales rep at your bigger competitor.
quotes.speaker: Jason Lemkin
quotes.context: Strategic positioning: founders can outcompete incumbents in early sales by outperforming reps on product depth.

quotes.topic_title: When to hire first reps and why two
quotes.text: I think as soon as you've got those 10 customers and more than 20% of your time is booked up with customers, you need leverage. You need leverage.
quotes.speaker: Jason Lemkin
quotes.context: A concrete threshold (10 customers + >20% founder time) for when to start hiring sales to avoid founder bandwidth becoming the bottleneck.

quotes.topic_title: When to hire first reps and why two
quotes.text: If you do it too early, if you're not spending 20% of your time in sales and 20% of your time in recruiting, you're failing as a founder. You need 20% of each, 20% in sales and 20% recruiting.
quotes.speaker: Jason Lemkin
quotes.context: A simple operating model for early-stage founders/CEOs that prioritizes sales and recruiting above most other activities.

quotes.topic_title: When to hire first reps and why two
quotes.text: So you need to hire one rep and you've got to hire two because otherwise, there's no A-B test. You have to A-B test humans. You have to A-B test humans. You've got to hire two as hard as it is,
quotes.speaker: Jason Lemkin
quotes.context: A counterintuitive hiring strategy: hire two reps to reduce risk and learn faster via an A/B test when early data is scarce.

quotes.topic_title: When to hire first reps and why two
quotes.text: Those first couple reps have to be people you would buy your own product from. That's it.
quotes.speaker: Jason Lemkin
quotes.context: A crisp selection criterion for early sales hires that cuts through resume/logo bias and focuses on trust and buyer-conviction.

quotes.topic_title: When to hire first reps and why two
quotes.text: Leads are so precious in the early days. It's so hard to find leads. That's the problem. You hire this perfect person from Snowflake and you have three leads a month and you give him two and he doesn't close them, your company's going to die. Leads are so precious.
quotes.speaker: Jason Lemkin
quotes.context: A vivid warning (with a specific example) about why “big-logo” hires can be dangerous when lead volume is low and every lead matters.

quotes.topic_title: Profile of early reps: people you’d buy from
quotes.text: you need two sales reps hitting quota closing deals before you're ready to hire a manager for them.
quotes.speaker: Jason Lemkin
quotes.context: A concrete hiring gate: prove repeatable rep-level success before adding management overhead.

quotes.topic_title: Profile of early reps: people you’d buy from
quotes.text: Almost all VPs of sales, their job is to take you from rep three to 300, to take you from three to 300, to take something that's just starting to repeat, a script that's just starting to work, leads that are just starting to come in.
quotes.speaker: Jason Lemkin
quotes.context: Defines the VP Sales role as a scaling function that assumes early repeatability already exists.

quotes.topic_title: Profile of early reps: people you’d buy from
quotes.text: Then take Lenny and Jason, the two reps I have, as quirky as they are, they're crushing it.
quotes.speaker: Jason Lemkin
quotes.context: Highlights that early winning reps may be “quirky” but effective—optimize for results over conventional profile fit.

quotes.topic_title: When to hire a VP of Sales
quotes.text: you need two sales reps hitting quota closing deals before you're ready to hire a manager for them.
quotes.speaker: Jason Lemkin
quotes.context: A clear hiring threshold that prevents bringing in sales leadership before the motion is proven.

quotes.topic_title: When to hire a VP of Sales
quotes.text: Almost all VPs of sales, their job is to take you from rep three to 300, to take you from three to 300, to take something that's just starting to repeat, a script that's just starting to work, leads that are just starting to come in.
quotes.speaker: Jason Lemkin
quotes.context: A memorable scaling framework that defines what VPs of Sales are actually optimized to do.

quotes.topic_title: When to hire a VP of Sales
quotes.text: So you need two reps that are hitting quota and then you hire VP of sales. If you hire it before then, you're doing a Hail Mary. It ain't going to work. It never, ever, never, ever, ever, never, ever works.
quotes.speaker: Jason Lemkin
quotes.context: A blunt warning that challenges the common “hire a VP to fix sales” instinct.

quotes.topic_title: When to hire a VP of Sales
quotes.text: You're asking them to find product market fit to be the first rep, to be the second rep and scale it all at the same time. It's mission impossible to do all four at the same time.
quotes.speaker: Jason Lemkin
quotes.context: A mental model for why early VP Sales hires fail: the role gets overloaded with incompatible jobs.

quotes.topic_title: When to hire a VP of Sales
quotes.text: That VP of sales will not be there in eight months. You know what else? 2 million of the four will be gone because they'll never understand the product.
quotes.speaker: Jason Lemkin
quotes.context: A concrete, high-stakes consequence (time + burn) of hiring sales leadership before product-savvy reps prove repeatability.

quotes.topic_title: Should VPs carry a bag and sell?
quotes.text: So I used to say I don't know if it matters, but what I've learned the last 18 to 20 months when everyone has gotten lazy, Lenny, everyone in tech has gotten lazy, is I see way too many VPs of sales that come in and never have any idea how to sell the product, never, never. They only want to be managers.
quotes.speaker: Jason Lemkin
quotes.context: Contrarian take that recent market conditions exposed a failure mode: sales leaders who manage but can’t actually sell the product.

quotes.topic_title: Should VPs carry a bag and sell?
quotes.text: Now, whether they carry a bag or whether what they do is they join calls with the reps, whether they backfill the reps, you want your VP of sales in deals 20, 30 hours a week when they start.
quotes.speaker: Jason Lemkin
quotes.context: Actionable operating bar for new VPs: spend heavy time directly in deals early to learn the product and sales motion fast.

quotes.topic_title: Should VPs carry a bag and sell?
quotes.text: Yeah. If you hire a VP of sales before then, it's approaching 100% chance of failure.
quotes.speaker: Jason Lemkin
quotes.context: Hard gating criterion (and strong warning) about timing: don’t hire a VP Sales before founders have proven early sales repeatability.

quotes.topic_title: Should VPs carry a bag and sell?
quotes.text: At least for a little while. More importantly, if they don't want to, I think in today's world you got to run from them. Exactly whether they fully carry a quota, a half quota, whether they backfill the sales team, you want a salesperson.
quotes.speaker: Jason Lemkin
quotes.context: Practical hiring filter: if a VP candidate resists selling work, treat it as a red flag regardless of the exact quota structure.

quotes.topic_title: Should VPs carry a bag and sell?
quotes.text: 2021 was crazy because everything was too crazy. There's too much money, too much going on. 2022 was the knife falling. That was crazy too. 2023 was just hard. Whether it's burnout or whatever out or just too much change, I would say I've probably interviewed for different reasons, 50 VPs of sales in the last 12 months, I would say the majority don't want to do sales. It's my first screening question. That's why they got to carry a bag because it proves they actually still care about the craft.
quotes.speaker: Jason Lemkin
quotes.context: Data point + methodology: use “do you still want to do sales?” as an early screen, and require a bag to validate commitment to the craft.

quotes.topic_title: Interview signals: customer obsession over process
quotes.text: One of the Colombo style questions I ask them, and this is so odd. It barely even counts as a question is, what do you want to do your first 30 days? What do you want to do? Actually, I usually ask, "What do you want to do your first two weeks?" In B2B, if I don't hear from the VP of sales or the VP of product that I'm going to go meet customers, out, I'm out.
quotes.speaker: Jason Lemkin
quotes.context: A simple interview prompt becomes a practical screening framework: customer contact in the first two weeks is a hard pass/fail signal.

quotes.topic_title: Interview signals: customer obsession over process
quotes.text: Every single great VP of product, chief product officer I've ever worked with in my entire career, you know what the first thing they do in the first two weeks? They're like, "Leave me alone. I'm going to go talk to 20 customers. Leave me alone."
quotes.speaker: Jason Lemkin
quotes.context: Sets a concrete bar (talk to ~20 customers fast) for what “great” product leadership behavior looks like immediately after joining.

quotes.topic_title: Interview signals: customer obsession over process
quotes.text: And when you hear that story of, "I don't want to travel out of Pleasanton," or they say, here's what you're going to hear from the wrong person for anything, even up to 50 million in revenue, "I'm going to spend that first month working on process," "I'm going to spend that first month getting Salesforce up and running," "I'm going to send the first month on territory planning, Lenny, because we really, with our three reps, I really want to make sure we've nailed territories, right? Lenny will do the south, Elaine will do the east, Jason will do the west."
quotes.speaker: Jason Lemkin
quotes.context: A vivid red-flag checklist: “process-first” onboarding plans (tools/territories) can signal the wrong hire even at meaningful scale.

quotes.topic_title: Interview signals: customer obsession over process
quotes.text: I literally just got this LinkedIn email to work with me at SaaStr, from this person who'd been reading SaaStr for eight years. You're like, "I want to run account management, customer success for you. Here's what's, you're doing wrong, here's how to do it." I'm like, "Oh, this is pretty good." And I DMed her back, I'm like, "Great. To be honest, you realize that you're actually going to have to talk to customers and sponsors yourself in the beginning." No response. Just out. Just out. And that was the best one I got the last 30 days. That was the best inbound that I personally got.
quotes.speaker: Jason Lemkin
quotes.context: A concrete hiring anecdote illustrating how “customer contact avoidance” shows up in real recruiting—and how to test for it directly.

quotes.topic_title: Interview signals: customer obsession over process
quotes.text: And if you hear a touch of cynicism, if you hear anger, if you hear, "I don't want to meet customers in any..." and I'm going to say any VP role, product, sales, marketing, customers... If they don't want to meet customers their first, let's make it a 14-day test, you know they're never going to want to meet customers.
quotes.speaker: Jason Lemkin
quotes.context: A blunt, actionable heuristic: reluctance to meet customers within 14 days predicts long-term customer avoidance across VP functions.

quotes.topic_title: Sales leaders must stay in big deals
quotes.text: But at Salesforce, they're trying to close $100-million-plus deals. You think that the sales leadership doesn't need to be in those deals? You think they can just hit refresh on the dashboards and track them from home? No.
quotes.speaker: Jason Lemkin
quotes.context: Challenges the idea that sales leaders can manage purely via dashboards when stakes are highest in enterprise deals.

quotes.topic_title: Sales leaders must stay in big deals
quotes.text: Marc Benioff today is still flying to meet customers.
quotes.speaker: Jason Lemkin
quotes.context: A concrete example that even at massive scale, top sales leadership stays directly involved with customers.

quotes.topic_title: Sales leaders must stay in big deals
quotes.text: And Salesforce drops millions of dollars, and he waits to meet customers, prospects, and partners in person all day, because it's efficient. Because it's efficient. Because he can do 50 or 100 customer or prospect meetings a day at Davos.
quotes.speaker: Jason Lemkin
quotes.context: Reframes high-touch executive selling as an efficiency play, not a vanity activity, using Davos as a high-leverage meeting hub.

quotes.topic_title: Sales leaders must stay in big deals
quotes.text: He's still doing it at 30-something billion in revenue.
quotes.speaker: Jason Lemkin
quotes.context: A scale-based data point underscoring that executive involvement in big deals doesn’t go away as companies grow.

quotes.topic_title: Sales leaders must stay in big deals
quotes.text: but most of your audience is not ready to hire at four billion or 10 billion in revenue. They're not ready to hire that person. Don't hire them, right?
quotes.speaker: Jason Lemkin
quotes.context: Actionable hiring advice: avoid bringing in a process-only sales leader too early if your company isn’t at mega-scale.

quotes.topic_title: How to interview early reps: demo the product
quotes.text: But it's not "Sell me this pen," it's "Sell me this app." So I don't like surprises, I don't like games. I like to do this in a second interview or whatever. Give them time.
quotes.speaker: Jason Lemkin
quotes.context: A practical interview framework: give candidates prep time, then have them demo/pitch the actual product to prove selling ability.

quotes.topic_title: How to interview early reps: demo the product
quotes.text: I am shocked how many salespeople I have met, Lenny, from SDR to SEB of sales that, by the time... And I'm doing an interview for a portfolio company, this isn't a screener interview, they haven't even watched an explainer video yet.
quotes.speaker: Jason Lemkin
quotes.context: A counterintuitive screening signal: many candidates don’t do basic product homework even deep into interview loops.

quotes.topic_title: How to interview early reps: demo the product
quotes.text: Because here's the mistake that 99% of founders and sales reps make. We're not really selling in B2B. We're solving problems.
quotes.speaker: Jason Lemkin
quotes.context: A memorable mental model shift from “selling” to “problem-solving” that reframes how reps should pitch and qualify.

quotes.topic_title: How to interview early reps: demo the product
quotes.text: As painful as that seems in tougher times, in 2024, the best reps say, "No, we're not there yet. We're not the right... If you need this feature, if you need this integration, I want you back in six months when you use this big product that isn't that great. But today, we're not the right solution for you."
quotes.speaker: Jason Lemkin
quotes.context: Consultative selling in practice: top reps build trust by confidently disqualifying bad-fit buyers rather than forcing a close.

quotes.topic_title: How to interview early reps: demo the product
quotes.text: I can't tell you, I would say 95% of the hiring I see out there, people don't do reference checks anymore, Lenny.
quotes.speaker: Jason Lemkin
quotes.context: A specific data point highlighting a widespread hiring-process regression that founders can immediately correct.

quotes.topic_title: Hiring rigor: reference checks and avoiding mis-hires
quotes.text: I can't tell you, I would say 95% of the hiring I see out there, people don't do reference checks anymore, Lenny.
quotes.speaker: Jason M Lemkin
quotes.context: A striking data point that highlights how common it’s become to skip a basic hiring safeguard, setting up avoidable mis-hires.

quotes.topic_title: Hiring rigor: reference checks and avoiding mis-hires
quotes.text: You're going to invest so much... Forget about the salary, it doesn't really matter. So much time, your time, your leads, everything's so precious, to bring Jason into your company and you're going to go through all this recruiting process and you're not even going to do any reference checks?
quotes.speaker: Jason M Lemkin
quotes.context: Reframes hiring cost around scarce resources (time/leads) and argues reference checks are irrational to skip given the true investment.

quotes.topic_title: Hiring rigor: reference checks and avoiding mis-hires
quotes.text: I mean, that poor CloudFlare woman that blew up with the thing, there's so many issues there we could dig into, but it's all Cloudflare fault for hiring her.
quotes.speaker: Jason M Lemkin
quotes.context: Uses a concrete example to emphasize the accountability model that hiring failure is primarily the company’s responsibility.

quotes.topic_title: Hiring rigor: reference checks and avoiding mis-hires
quotes.text: But remember, if you hire someone and they fail, it's all your fault.
quotes.speaker: Jason M Lemkin
quotes.context: A memorable accountability principle founders can use to tighten hiring rigor and onboarding expectations.

quotes.topic_title: Hiring rigor: reference checks and avoiding mis-hires
quotes.text: So, tying it back, that's why you've got to do this, "Sell me this pen." You've got to, before you hire the salesperson, have them sell your product real. Do the demo.
quotes.speaker: Jason M Lemkin
quotes.context: Actionable methodology: require realistic work-sample tests (a real demo) to validate sales ability before hiring.
